docs.text: This site contains daily important news 2026. Use the sidebar to navigate by Year → Month → Day.

docs.title: Polity
Headline: Budget Presentation and Parliamentary Procedures
docs.text:
• The Union Budget is presented by the Ministry of Finance, specifically the Budget Division within the Department of Economic Affairs.
  • A budget must be passed by the Lok Sabha; failure to do so can lead to the government losing confidence and the Prime Minister resigning.
  • The term "budget" is not explicitly mentioned in the Indian Constitution; instead, Article 112 refers to it as the "Annual Financial Statement".
  • The concept of presenting the budget in a briefcase originated with British Budget Chief William E. Gladstone in 1860.
  • R.K. Shanmukham Chetty presented the first independent Indian budget in 1947.
  • Nirmala Sitharaman holds the record for the longest budget speech in terms of duration, while Manmohan Singh's longest speech was in terms of word count.
  • Historically, the budget was presented in the evening at 5 PM; this was changed to 11 AM by Yashwant Sinha.
  • Arun Jaitley shifted the budget presentation date to February 1st, and this has been followed since 2016.
  • Prior to 2017, the Railway Budget was presented separately; it has since been merged with the Union Budget.
  • Only three Prime Ministers (Jawaharlal Nehru, Indira Gandhi, and Rajiv Gandhi) have presented the budget.
  • Morarji Desai has presented the most budgets (10 times), with Nirmala Sitharaman closely following.
  • Article 280 of the Constitution establishes the Finance Commission to distribute central tax revenue among states.
  • The 16th Finance Commission's recommendation for states to receive 41% of divisible central taxes has been accepted.
  • Union Territories do not have a separate budget as they fall under the direct control of the Central Government.

docs.title: Economy
Headline: Union Budget 2026: Receipts, Expenditures, and Fiscal Health
docs.text:
• The Union Budget for 2026-27 projects total receipts of ₹53.4 lakh crore, comprising ₹18.1 lakh crore from Capital Receipts and ₹35.3 lakh crore from Revenue Receipts.
  • Total expenditure for 2026-27 is estimated at ₹58.4 lakh crore, with ₹17 lakh crore allocated for Capital Expenditure and ₹41.3 lakh crore for Revenue Expenditure.
  • The government's primary sources of revenue include:
    1. borrowings and liabilities (24%),
    2. income tax (21%),
    3. corporate tax (18%),
    4. GST and other indirect taxes (15%), and
    5. non-tax revenue (10%).
  • Government expenditures are primarily allocated to:
    1. state share of taxes (22%),
    2. interest payments (20%),
    3. central sector schemes (17%),
    4. and defense (11%).
  • The fiscal deficit for 2026-27 is projected to be approximately ₹5 lakh crore, reflecting an expenditure > revenue.
  • The budget emphasizes increasing capital expenditure to boost infrastructure development and economic growth.
  • Revenue receipts are defined as income that does not create a liability or reduce government assets, including tax and non-tax revenue.
  • Capital receipts include borrowings, recovery of loans, and disinvestment, which either create a liability or reduce government assets.
  • Revenue expenditure includes day-to-day operational costs like salaries, pensions, and subsidies, which do not create assets.
  • Capital expenditure is considered growth-oriented as it involves spending on assets like infrastructure (roads, railways, buildings), which can generate future income.
  • The government aims to reduce the debt-to-GDP ratio to 50% (+/- 1%) by 2030. The current ratio for 2024-25/2025-26 is 56.1%.
  • The budget includes a ₹100 crore fund for MSME Growth Fund and the establishment of "Corporate Mitra" to support small businesses.
  • A "Trade Receivables e-Discounting System" (TReDS) platform will mandate transaction settlements for MSMEs to ensure timely payments.
  • The government plans to invest in the India Semiconductor Mission 2.0, biopharma research, and the production of rare earth permanent magnets.
  • Initiatives for the textile sector, electronic manufacturing, and MSMEs are planned, including customs duty exemptions on raw materials for manufacturing.
  • The budget allocates ₹7.85 lakh crore for defense in 2026, a 15% increase.
  • Education spending for 2026-27 is projected at ₹1.39 lakh crore, a slight increase from the previous year's ₹1.28 lakh crore.
  • The government is focusing on urbanization, with plans for seven high-speed rail corridors and development in Tier 2 and Tier 3 cities.
  • The budget proposes developing temple towns and improving the ease of doing business.
  • Government transfers to states and Union Territories are projected at ₹26.2 lakh crore for 2026-27.
  • Focus areas for development include coconut and cashew cultivation, and the wood sector.

docs.title: Other
Headline: Budget 2026: Key Focus Areas and Historical Context
docs.text:
• The Union Budget for 2026 was the primary focus of the analysis, covering its historical evolution and economic implications.
  • The analysis delved into the origin of the word "budget" from the French word "bugget" meaning a leather briefcase.
  • Historical context of budget presentation, including the shift from leather briefcases to "Bahi Khata" and then to digital formats, was discussed.
  • The "Halwa ceremony" preceding budget finalization, where officials involved are secluded to maintain confidentiality, was explained.
  • The process of budget printing, which was initially in Rashtrapati Bhavan and later shifted to North Block basement due to a leak in 1950, was detailed.
  • The budget mentions government efforts in urbanization, including the development of city economic regions and seven high-speed rail corridors.
  • The budget highlights a focus on the development of coconut and cashew cultivation in India.
  • The concept of "rupee coming from and rupee going to" was explained, detailing government revenue and expenditure.
  • The analysis provided a detailed breakdown of various receipts (revenue and capital) and expenditures (revenue and capital) as per the budget.
  • The importance of understanding economic terms like Fiscal Deficit, Debt-to-GDP ratio, Revenue Deficit, Capital Receipts, Revenue Receipts, Capital Expenditure, and Revenue Expenditure was stressed.
  • The budget is structured around three core questions: where the government gets money from, where it spends, and the resulting deficits.
  • The narrative emphasizes that developing economies like India typically face budget deficits due to higher expenditures.

docs.title: International Relations
Headline: India successfully tests Solid Fuel Ducted Ramjet (SFDR) technology, enhancing air-to-air missile capabilities.
docs.text:
• India, in collaboration with Russia, has successfully tested the Solid Fuel Ducted Ramjet (SFDR) technology.
  • This technology is a missile propulsion system that uses a ramjet engine, an air-breathing jet engine that compresses incoming air to create high pressure for combustion.
  • The SFDR technology will enhance the combat effectiveness and range of India's long-range air-to-air missiles.
  • Missiles equipped with SFDR technology fly at supersonic speeds, are highly maneuverable, and difficult to intercept as they obtain oxygen from the atmosphere.
  • This technological advancement places India among a select few countries possessing this capability.

docs.title: Polity
Headline: Supreme Court questions WhatsApp on data privacy and consent practices.
docs.text:
• The Supreme Court has raised concerns regarding WhatsApp's data access and the clarity of its consent mechanisms for users.
  • The court questioned how advertisements related to personal chats appear, implying a potential breach of privacy.
  • WhatsApp's claim of end-to-end encryption was challenged, with the court asking for simplified consent language understandable to the common person.
  • The court emphasized that user consent for data access does not grant permission for commercial exploitation, sale, or purchase of personal data.
  • The Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023, and Article 21 (Right to Privacy) were highlighted as crucial legal frameworks governing data protection in India.
  • The court warned that if Meta, WhatsApp's parent company, violates the right to privacy, it may not be allowed to operate in India.

docs.title: Headline: MP Local Area Development (MPLAD) Scheme faces scrutiny over underutilization and corruption allegations.
docs.text:
• The Member of Parliament Local Area Development (MPLAD) Scheme, a Centrally Sponsored Scheme, allows MPs to recommend development projects worth ₹5 crore annually.
  • Reports indicate significant underutilization of funds by some Members of Parliament, particularly in Delhi, where substantial amounts remain unspent and carry forward.
  • Allegations of corruption, including non-existent projects, fake claims, and the involvement of single vendors potentially linked to MPs, have surfaced.
  • There is a mandatory provision for MPs to allocate a minimum of 15% of their funds for projects benefiting Scheduled Castes and 7.5% for Scheduled Tribes.
  • Nominated Rajya Sabha MPs can recommend projects anywhere in India, while elected Rajya Sabha MPs can recommend projects within their state, and Lok Sabha MPs within their constituency.
  • The Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation (MoSPI) oversees the scheme, with District Administrations responsible for implementation.
  • The scheme is non-lapsable, meaning unused funds carry forward to the next financial year, accumulating over the MP's tenure.

docs.title: Headline: NAMASTE Scheme aims to mechanize sanitation work and eliminate manual scavenging.
docs.text:
• The National Action for Mechanized Sanitation Ecosystem (NAMASTE) Scheme, a joint initiative of the Ministry of Social Justice and Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs, aims to mechanize sanitation work.
  • Launched in 2022, the scheme's primary objective is to replace manual scavenging with machine-based cleaning.
  • Profiling of sanitation workers in urban areas is being conducted to identify those engaged in waste picking and sanitation.
  • Data reveals that a significant majority (84%) of identified sanitation workers belong to Scheduled Caste, Scheduled Tribe, and Other Backward Classes communities.
  • Some states like Delhi and Goa show a higher proportion of sanitation workers from the General Category.
  • The scheme is implemented by the National Safai Karamchari Finance and Development Corporation and aims to provide health insurance, safety measures, and rehabilitation to sanitation workers.

docs.title: Headline: Supreme Court's approach to death penalty cases highlights concerns over judicial adherence to guidelines.
docs.text:
• The Supreme Court has not confirmed any death penalty sentences in the last three years, though lower courts continue to award them.
  • Lower courts are observed to frequently award the death penalty, often without strictly adhering to the "rarest of rare" doctrine established by the Supreme Court.
  • In 2023, lower courts sentenced 128 individuals to death, but the confirmation rate by High Courts and the Supreme Court remains very low.
  • The Supreme Court, in cases like Bachan Singh vs. State of Punjab (1980), has laid down guidelines for awarding the death penalty, including the "rarest of rare" principle, requiring brutal murders, depraved motives, and significant crimes.
  • Guidelines also stipulate a minimum 15-day gap between conviction and sentencing to allow for psychological preparation, which is often overlooked by subordinate courts.
  • The constitutionality of the death penalty has been upheld, but its application remains a subject of debate due to concerns about fairness, deterrence, and human rights.

docs.title: Economy
Headline: US-India trade deal details remain unclear; tariff on steel and penalty on oil imports reduced.
docs.text:
• Specific details regarding the US-India trade deal are still pending clarification, with the Commerce Minister stating that more information will be available upon signing.
  • While the trade deal has been announced, it has not yet been formally signed.
  • A significant development is the reduction of the 25% penalty on India's oil imports from Russia to zero.
  • The tariff on steel has been reduced from 25% to 18%.
  • The impact of these tariff reductions on India's exports, particularly in sectors like leather and carpets, is expected to be positive.
  • The concept of "reciprocal tariffs" as employed by the Trump administration, where the US imposed tariffs based on tariffs levied by other countries, was discussed.
  • Government assurances indicate that farmers and exporters have been considered, and strategic sectors will be protected.

docs.title: Headline: AI investment to shift focus from infrastructure to applications for higher returns.
docs.text:
• The next wave of investment in Artificial Intelligence (AI) is predicted to move from infrastructure (data centers, semiconductors) towards applications and platforms.
  • While significant investment has gone into AI infrastructure, companies developing AI applications and platforms are expected to generate higher profits.
  • The article highlights that businesses investing in AI applications have seen substantial profit increases.
  • India is preparing to host an AI summit, making AI a significant topic for potential UPSC questions, following similar patterns from previous summits.
  • AI is viewed as a double-edged sword, offering benefits like increased efficiency and cost reduction, but also posing challenges such as job displacement, misinformation, and cybercrime.
  • The potential for AI to impact environmental concerns, including energy consumption in data centers, is also noted.

docs.title: Headline: India's industrial shift towards clean energy and electrification is crucial for future growth.
docs.text:
• The future of industrial growth lies in transitioning from fossil fuels (oil, coal, gas) to clean electricity, referred to as "electrons."
  • Countries that embrace this shift will reduce emissions, enhance supply chain control, create jobs, and attract capital.
  • China's rapid industrial electrification and significant investment in renewable energy (solar, hydro, nuclear) are cited as examples of successful transition.
  • Reliable and clean electricity supply is critical for industries, and India needs to focus on ensuring 24/7 power availability to its industrial sectors to become a global manufacturing hub.
  • The transition to clean energy is presented not just as an environmental imperative but also a developmental and strategic necessity to reduce import dependency and achieve energy autonomy.
  • The article suggests that while initial costs of clean energy technologies are high, increasing demand and production, potentially including hydrogen, can lead to cost reduction and greater accessibility.

docs.title: Environment
Headline: AI's environmental impact includes increased electricity consumption and heat generation from data centers.
docs.text:
• The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) leads to significant electricity consumption, particularly in data centers.
  • This increased electricity demand, if met by coal-fired power plants, contributes to environmental pollution.
  • Data processing within AI systems generates heat, which has direct environmental implications.
  • Cooling data centers requires substantial water resources, adding to environmental concerns.

docs.title: Science & Tech
Headline: India's successful test of SFDR technology positions it among leading missile technology nations.
docs.text:
• The successful test of Solid Fuel Ducted Ramjet (SFDR) technology by India marks a significant advancement in missile propulsion.
  • This technology is crucial for developing next-generation air-to-air missiles with extended range and superior maneuverability.
  • The SFDR is an air-breathing jet engine that utilizes atmospheric oxygen for combustion, reducing the need for onboard oxidizers and thus increasing missile range and payload capacity.
  • This development is a result of collaborative efforts, likely involving international partnerships, and strengthens India's defense technological capabilities.

docs.title: Other
Headline: Supreme Court questions WhatsApp on data privacy and consent practices.
docs.text:
• The Supreme Court is examining the practices of social media platforms like WhatsApp concerning user data privacy.
  • Concerns have been raised about how personal data, even from seemingly encrypted chats, is accessed and potentially used for targeted advertising.
  • The court is emphasizing the need for clear, understandable consent mechanisms and strict adherence to data protection laws like the Digital Personal Data Protection Act, 2023.
  • The ruling highlights the intersection of technology, privacy rights, and legal regulations in the digital age.

docs.title: Headline: NAMASTE Scheme focuses on rehabilitation and mechanization of sanitation work.
docs.text:
• The NAMASTE Scheme is addressing the socio-economic challenges faced by sanitation workers, often from marginalized communities.
  • By promoting mechanization, the scheme aims to eliminate hazardous manual scavenging, thereby improving the safety and dignity of workers.
  • The profiling of workers is a crucial step towards identifying needs and providing targeted support, including health insurance and skill development.
  • This initiative underscores the government's commitment to social justice and the welfare of vulnerable sections of society.

docs.title: Headline: Death penalty in India: Lower courts' high sentencing rate contrasted with Supreme Court's cautious approach.
docs.text:
• An analysis of death penalty cases reveals a significant disparity between the sentencing patterns of lower courts and the confirmation rate by higher judicial bodies.
  • Lower courts frequently award the death penalty, sometimes without fully adhering to established legal precedents like the "rarest of rare" doctrine.
  • The Supreme Court, in its review of these cases, tends to commute death sentences, emphasizing the gravity of the offense and the necessity for strict adherence to procedural safeguards.
  • This trend raises questions about the consistency and fairness of capital punishment application across the judicial system.

docs.title: Polity
Headline: Manipur President's Rule Ends, New Chief Minister Takes Office Amidst Ongoing Political Developments
docs.text:
• President's Rule in Manipur, which was imposed last year, has now ended.
  • A new Chief Minister has taken office in Manipur.
  • The imposition of President's Rule in Manipur was a consequence of significant violence that occurred in May 2023, leading to displacement and loss of life.
  • Manipur has a history of frequent President's Rule impositions, with the recent one being the 11th instance.
  • The first President's Rule in Manipur lasted for 66 days from March 12 to March 19, 1967.
  • The longest duration of President's Rule in Manipur was 2 years and 157 days, from October 17, 1969, to March 2, 1972.
  • Another instance of President's Rule in Manipur lasted for approximately 277 days, from June 2, 2001, to March 6, 2002.
  • President's Rule, also known as State Emergency or Constitutional Emergency, is covered under Article 356 of the Indian Constitution.
  • It can be imposed if a state government is not functioning according to the Constitution, or if a state government fails to implement directions from the Central Government (Article 365).
  • Article 355 obliges the Union to protect states against external aggression and internal disturbances, which can be a ground for President's Rule.
  • Article 357 empowers the President to make laws for a state under President's Rule.
  • Grounds for imposing President's Rule include breakdown of constitutional machinery (e.g., government collapse, lack of majority) and failure to implement Central Government directions.
  • Other reasons can include hung assemblies, election delays due to natural disasters, or war.
  • Imposing President's Rule requires parliamentary approval within two months of the President's declaration.
  • Initially, President's Rule is imposed for six months and can be extended for up to three years with subsequent parliamentary approvals every six months.
  • The President can revoke President's Rule without parliamentary approval.
  • When President's Rule is in effect, governance of the state comes under the Central Government, the state legislature may be suspended or dissolved, and the President exercises executive control.
  • The judiciary, specifically the High Court, remains unaffected by President's Rule.
  • The Supreme Court in S.R. Bommai vs. Union of India (1994) held that the imposition of President's Rule is subject to judicial review.
  • The Supreme Court in Rameshwar Prasad Case (2006) stated that the recommendation for imposing President's Rule must be based on objective criteria, not merely the subjective opinion of the Central Government.
  • The Sarkaria Commission (1988) recommended that President's Rule should be invoked only as a last resort, considering its negative impact on federalism.
  • The Punchhi Commission (2010) suggested that President's Rule should be applied only to the specific area where violence or disturbance has occurred, rather than the entire state.
  • Criticisms of President's Rule include its frequent use, potential for centralization of power, disruption of democratic processes, and misuse for political motives.

docs.title: Social Justice
Headline: Denotified Tribes Demand Constitutional Recognition and Separate Census Entry Amidst Persistent Disadvantage
docs.text:
• Denotified Tribes (DNTs) are demanding constitutional recognition and a separate entry in the upcoming census.
  • Historically, these communities were labeled as "Criminal Tribes" under the British-era Criminal Tribes Act of 1871.
  • The Criminal Tribes Act was repealed in 1952, and these communities were then termed Denotified Tribes.
  • DNTs argue that despite the removal of the "criminal" tag, they continue to face social discrimination and economic backwardness.
  • Many members of DNTs are currently categorized under Scheduled Castes (SC), Scheduled Tribes (ST), or Other Backward Classes (OBC), while a significant portion remains unclassified, limiting their access to reservation benefits.
  • They are advocating for a distinct identity and separate reservation benefits, similar to SC, ST, and OBC categories.
  • The upcoming census in 2027 will include a caste-based enumeration for the first time since 1931, presenting an opportunity for DNTs to seek a separate column.
  • DNTs are concerned that if they are not included as a separate category in the 2027 census, they may be overlooked again.
  • They are seeking a separate constitutional schedule, akin to Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.
  • The population of DNTs, along with Nomadic and Semi-Nomadic Tribes, is estimated to be around 10% of India's total population.
  • Previous attempts to support DNTs include the Renke Commission and the Aided Commission (2014), which recommended a permanent National Commission.
  • The Seed Scheme, implemented by the Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment, aims to provide support to DNTs but has reportedly seen underutilization of its budget (₹70 crore spent out of a ₹200 crore budget from 2021-2026).
  • A major issue highlighted is the lack of caste certificates for DNTs, which prevents them from availing benefits from various welfare schemes and institutional support (e.g., scholarships, housing).
  • The Welfare Board for Denotified, Nomadic and Semi-Nomadic Communities (DWBDNC), set up in February 2019, is reportedly dysfunctional due to lack of funding, staff, and leadership.
  • The Supreme Court in August 2024 acknowledged that many DNTs within SC and ST categories require subclassifications and targeted support.
  • The National Commission for Denotified, Nomadic and Semi-Nomadic Tribes, headed by Biku Ramji Idate, identified over 1200 communities that require recognition and support.

docs.title: Environment & Disaster Management
Headline: 18 Dead in Illegal Meghalaya Mine Blast, Highlighting Persistent Rat-Hole Mining Dangers
docs.text:
• An explosion in an illegal coal mine in Meghalaya's East Jaintia Hills district resulted in the deaths of 18 people.
  • The incident underscores the ongoing problem of illegal coal mining, specifically "rat-hole mining," in Meghalaya, despite being banned by the National Green Tribunal (NGT).
  • Rat-hole mining involves creating narrow tunnels, often by children, to extract coal, lacking structural support and posing extreme safety risks.
  • Historical incidents of fatalities due to rat-hole mining in Meghalaya have occurred repeatedly since at least 2012, with casualties in 2012 (15), 2013 (5), 2018 (15), and 2021 (6).
  • The practice continues due to the difficulty of extracting thin veins of coal scattered over large areas and the private ownership of land where coal is found, bypassing government control.
  • The recent incident involved a blast, likely due to dynamites, trapping workers and leading to their deaths.
  • The Meghalaya government has ordered an inquiry, registered FIRs under various acts, and announced ex-gratia compensation for the deceased's families.
  • Past committees, like the Justice BP Katakey Committee, have reportedly failed to bring about significant change in addressing rat-hole mining.
  • Environmental damage, including water contamination, is a significant consequence of this mining practice.

docs.title: Polity & Governance
Headline: Minor Forest Produce Procurement Drops 92%, Affecting Tribal Livelihoods
docs.text:
• Government procurement of Minor Forest Produce (MFP) has seen a drastic decline of 92% in 2024-25 compared to the previous year, as reported in Parliament.
  • MFP includes non-timber forest products like tendu leaves, honey, bamboo, mahua flowers, and medicinal herbs, which are a primary livelihood source for tribal communities.
  • The government purchases MFP at Minimum Support Price (MSP) to provide a fair income and prevent exploitation by middlemen.
  • The Ministry of Tribal Affairs, along with state governments and agencies like TRIFED, is responsible for implementing this procurement.
  • Despite ₹319 crore in funds released by the central government to states for MFP procurement, actual purchases have significantly decreased, impacting tribal incomes.
  • This decline is considered a Centrally Sponsored Scheme, meaning states are primarily responsible for the actual procurement with financial support from the center.
  • The situation may force tribal communities to rely on private traders, potentially leading to exploitation.

docs.title: Headline: Forest Rights Act 2006: Empowering Forest Dwellers and Protecting Livelihoods
docs.text:
• The Scheduled Tribes and Other Traditional Forest Dwellers (Recognition of Forest Rights) Act, 2006 (FRA) aims to protect the rights of forest-dwelling communities.
  • The Act recognizes and vests forest rights in, and ownership of, forest-dwelling Scheduled Tribes and Other Traditional Forest Dwellers.
  • FRA does not grant new rights but strengthens existing ones, focusing on community rights over forest land and resources.
  • Key provisions include rights to habitat, cultivation on occupied land (before December 13, 2005), and ownership of Minor Forest Produce (MFP).
  • Section 3(1)(c) of FRA specifically grants forest dwellers the ownership of MFP, although they cannot sell or transfer this ownership.
  • The Act promotes self-governance, poverty reduction, and livelihood security for tribal communities.
  • Rights are heritable, allowing for transfer to the next generation, and joint registration promotes gender justice.
  • The Ministry of Tribal Affairs is the nodal agency for implementing FRA at the national level.
  • Past UPSC questions have tested understanding of FRA, including its definition of bamboo as MFP and its provision of ownership rights.

docs.title: Science & Technology
Headline: India Develops Super Fast Charging Sodium-Ion Battery: A Potential Lithium-Ion Alternative
docs.text:
• Indian scientists have developed a super fast-charging sodium-ion battery capable of charging to 80% in just 6 minutes.
  • This new technology has a lifespan of over 3,000 charge cycles, offering significant durability.
  • Sodium-ion batteries utilize sodium ions (Na+) as charge carriers, similar to how lithium ions (Li+) work in lithium-ion batteries.
  • The working principle involves the movement of sodium ions between the anode and cathode during discharge and charging, mediated by an electrolyte.
  • Unlike lithium-ion batteries, which rely on scarce and geopolitically sensitive minerals like lithium, cobalt, and nickel, sodium-ion batteries use abundant and cheaper raw materials.
  • Sodium is readily available from sources like seawater and common salt (NaCl).
  • The use of aluminum as the current collector in sodium-ion batteries makes them potentially cheaper than copper-based lithium-ion batteries.
  • Advantages include safer transportation at zero voltage, reduced fire risk, and better thermal stability compared to lithium-ion batteries.
  • While current sodium-ion batteries have lower energy density than lithium-ion batteries, ongoing research and development, particularly in layered oxide sodium cathodes, aims to bridge this gap.
  • These batteries are seen as a viable alternative for electric vehicles (especially two- and three-wheelers), grid storage, and consumer electronics, supporting India's clean energy goals.
  • India needs a coordinated approach, including policy, R&D, and market creation, to adopt and produce sodium-ion batteries.
  • A 2025 UPSC question highlighted that cobalt, lithium, and nickel are used in the cathodes of electric vehicle batteries, with graphite used in anodes.
